title: Hendrix seeking to begin rowing as a club sport
text:
Hendrix seeking to begin rowing as a club sport Posted: October 24, 2015 - 12:25pm 
By ANDY ROBERTSON 
LOG CABIN STAFF WRITER 
Hendrix College is exploring starting a rowing club, with a goal of starting competition during the spring semester. 
Because the students are not competing under the NCAA jurisdiction, it will be a club sport. 
The Hendrix club will likely against clubs from Rhodes College (a fellow Southern Athletic Association member), Northwestern State University (Southland Conference), Texas A&M–Galveston and Samford University. 
When competition begins next fall fall, the club will compete against other clubs in Louisiana, Oklahoma and Texas. 
“The goal is for students to have a fun recreational experience, learning the fundamentals of rowing, which includes rhythm, teamwork and synchronization,” volunteer and current coach Michelle Teague said. 
Teague has competed with RowAmerica North Little Rock in the Six Bridges Regatta on Sept. 19 on the Arkansas River. She placed fifth in Mixed Masters Double Sculls. She also competed Mixed Masters Single Scull, where she finished third and Mixed Open Eight, where the Arkansas Boathouse Club finished third. 
Teague also worked on the regatta organizing committee to recruit clubs to the second regatta. 
A scull refers to athletes with two oars – one in each hand. For races, there are three sculling events: the single, double and the quad. A race is called a regatta. 
RowAmerica North Little Rock competes under parent organization, US Rowing. 
For starters, Hendrix will be using a quad scull to an eight-person team called an octuple scull. As the team gets more experience rowing, Teague thinks the team will get single and double scull teams together. 
Hendrix alumnus Jim Smith, whom Teague said came up with the idea to bring a rowing club to Hendrix, is helping coach students until a longterm option gets filled. 
Teague said she thinks a Hendrix faculty sponsor was found Wednesday, so the club can start gaining traction. The club is looking to start holding boats at Beaverfork Lake so the team can practice there. However, until this happens, the team is working on land and indoor rowing machines, learning safe rowing techniques. 
“At our first meeting, we had a good amount of students interested in the club,” Teague said. 
At the first meeting for the club, 18 students showed up with six to 10 people of core leadership signing an agreement to compete.
